author: By Chang Che and Olivia Wang
title: No Joke: China Fines a Comedy Firm $2 Million for ‘Insulting’ the Military
description: The penalty came after a popular comedian joked about a military slogan often used by China’s leader, Xi Jinping, who has strictly curbed expression.
content: Beijing fined a Chinese comedy studio around $2 million on Wednesday for a joke that compared China’s military to stray dogs, a reminder of the ever-narrowing confines of expression under the country’s leader, Xi Jinping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Bard President Received $150,000 From Foundation Created by Jeffrey Epstein
description: Leon Botstein, the president of Bard College, said that he donated the money to his school as part of a $1 million gift he gave in 2016.
content: Leon Botstein, the president of Bard College, personally received $150,000 for consulting fees in 2016 from a foundation created by Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced billionaire accused of sexually abusing teenage girls, The Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Marlene Bauer Hagge, Last of the L.P.G.A.’s Founders, Dies at 89
description: Emerging on the national scene at 13, she went on to win 26 pro tournaments, including the 1956 L.P.G.A. Championship. She and 12 other women started the league.
content: Marlene Bauer Hagge, the last surviving founder of the Ladies Professional Golf Association and a member of its Hall of Fame, died on Tuesday in Rancho Mirage, Calif. She was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 17, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, May 17, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about the final report from the special counsel examining the origins of the Russia investigation misspelled the surname of a former Trump campaign aide. He is George Papadopoulos, not Papadopoulus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Orr
title: ‘Ted Lasso,’ Season 3, Episode 10 Recap: The Rich Are Different
description: How quickly can a story line end? Very quickly.
content: Do you remember when you were young and — at least if you were like me — you frequently misjudged how much space you had on a line to write what you intended, resulting in smaller and smaller, tightly squeezed letters as you approached the edge of the page? I feel as though that is where we find ourselves now in “Ted Lasso,” with just two episodes left in what is still theoretically the show’s last season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: An Insider’s View of the George Floyd Murder Trial
description: Minnesota’s attorney general, Keith Ellison, who jotted notes to himself daily as he oversaw the prosecution, has written a book about the case.
content: The country was riveted for three weeks in 2021 during the trial of the former police officer Derek Chauvin, as a jury in Minneapolis considered whether the death of George Floyd was murder. Through it all, Keith Ellison, the attorney general of Minnesota who was directing the prosecution, was a constant yet silent presence in the courtroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle and Pam Belluck
title: Appeals Court Seems Skeptical of F.D.A.’s Approval and Regulation of Abortion Pill
description: A panel of three judges heard arguments in a lawsuit by anti-abortion groups asking courts to order a widely used drug off the market.
content: A federal appeals court on Wednesday appeared prepared to rule that the availability of a commonly used abortion pill should be curtailed, showing skepticism of the decisions that the Food and Drug Administration has made about the drug.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What Americans Don’t Understand About China
description: A lot gets lost in translation. The Chinese-born economist Keyu Jin wants to change that.
content: Keyu Jin is in the West but not entirely of it. She’s fluent in English and French, studied at Harvard and teaches at the London School of Economics. She knows her way around Goldman Sachs and the World Bank. But she is still a proud Chinese. She lived with her parents in Beijing during two recent maternity leaves. And she has just written a book about what she calls “reading China in the original.” Unfiltered, that is, by a Western perspective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: In Broadway’s ‘Grey House,’ Something Nightmarish This Way Comes
description: Levi Holloway on his psychological thriller starring Laurie Metcalf: “It wears the jacket of horror. But I think it’s more heart than horror.”
content: When it comes to plays that inspire fear, unsettle the audience or display horrific intensity, only a handful come to mind. Martin McDonagh’s gruesome “The Pillowman” is one. Tracy Letts came up with two: the gleefully nasty thriller “Killer Joe” and the paranoia tale “Bug.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Welcome to Richie’s World
description: Richie Shazam, a model and downtown artist, has made an explosive book of self-portraits.
content: For Richie Shazam, becoming a Bollywood princess was not a manifestation. It was a realization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen and Justin Porter
title: Biden Heads to Japan for the G7
description: Also, global heat to rise over the next five years. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: President Biden left this afternoon for Japan to attend the annual Group of 7 summit meeting, which begins tomorrow in Hiroshima. Leaders of the major industrial democracies will discuss efforts to keep the global economy stable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Washington Confronts the Challenge of Policing A.I.
description: Lawmakers and Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, agreed that artificial intelligence should be regulated. How to do that remains an open question.
content: The fireworks that usually pop when technology executives testify before Congress were noticeably absent from yesterday’s Senate hearing on artificial intelligence. Instead, lawmakers questioned Sam Altman, the C.E.O. of OpenAI, for three hours in what appeared to be a genuine effort to understand the growing importance, and the dangers, of artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: The Mets Get a Shot of Offense by Calling Up a Top Prospect
description: Mark Vientos, a slugging infielder, was summoned from the minors to help a team that has struggled despite a high payroll.
content: The Mets called up Mark Vientos, a power-hitting infielder, in hopes of sparking their flagging offense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Casting a Bright Light on the Supreme Court’s ‘Shadow Docket’
description: A new book by the legal scholar Stephen Vladeck argues that unsigned and unexplained decisions issued through the court’s shadow docket have helped propel its jurisprudence to the right.
content: “Because Y is a crooked letter”: The first time I heard a parent saying this to her child it took me a few beats to understand what she meant. The boy had been asking, “Why?” about a perceived injustice — an order to leave the playground before he was ready. The mother’s response was simply a poetic variation of that old standby “Because I said so.” No explanation was forthcoming because none was needed. Mom was laying down the law. The kid had to obey it. Case closed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Riley Mellen and Haley Willis
title: Russian-Controlled Dam Risks Flooding in Southern Ukraine
description: The development is a dramatic turnabout after the reservoir had reached a historic low. The dam, which lies along the front line, has been a point of tension throughout the war.
content: Water levels at a reservoir that supplies southern Ukraine with drinking water have reached a 30-year high, increasing the possibility of flooding in the area and signaling a lack of regulation. The sudden increase in levels at the Kakhovka reservoir appears in altimetry data — which uses satellites to measure height — published on Friday by Theia, a French earth data provider.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Kaitlan Collins, Moderator of Trump Forum, Is Named CNN’s 9 P.M. Anchor
description: The appointment caps a fast rise at the network by Ms. Collins, 31, who previously covered the Trump and Biden administrations.
content: CNN has selected Kaitlan Collins to host a new weeknight show at 9 p.m., elevating her to one of the most coveted time slots in cable news a week after she moderated a contentious town hall with former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Husband’s Children Stopped Talking to Him After They Saw His Will. Help!
description: A reader’s adult stepchildren want nothing to do with her or their father after learning that the couple plan to leave their estates to each other. Should he reach out?
content: My husband and I, both 70, were married two years ago after living together for 20 years. When we shared our plans with his grown children, then 25 and 28, they were angry. His son demanded to see my husband’s will, which my husband showed him. In it, he leaves his entire estate to me, just as I leave mine to him. His son had hoped to inherit my husband’s New York loft and pay me an allowance. Eventually, the loft will go to his two children, and our upstate property will go to them and my daughter. Still, his children accused him angrily of not putting family first. It has now been two years since they spoke to their father. In their last conversation, my husband said he loved them and was always there to talk. Should he reach out to them, or is the onus on them to apologize? Also, should we tell them we’ve decided to sell the loft?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: U.S. Recorded Nearly 110,000 Overdose Deaths in 2022
description: The number leveled off after two years of sharp increases, according to new data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
content: Nearly 110,000 people died last year of drug overdoses in the United States, according to preliminary federal data published on Wednesday, a staggering figure that nonetheless represented a plateau after two years of sharp increases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Formula 1 Cancels Grand Prix Amid Deadly Floods in Italy
description: Safety concerns prompted the decision to call off the race at Imola, the site of this weekend’s Emilia-Romagna Grand Prix.
content: Formula 1 on Wednesday canceled this weekend’s Emilia-Romagna Grand Prix after heavy rain and deadly flooding in northern Italy made it unsafe to proceed with the race at Imola.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Introducing a New Audio App for Our Journalism and Storytelling
description: New York Times Audio provides news, depth and serendipity.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: Baseball Returns to the ‘Hallowed Grounds’ of a Negro Leagues Stadium
description: Saved from demolition, Hinchliffe Stadium in New Jersey underwent a $100 million renovation. It will now serve as a minor league ballpark and a Negro leagues museum.
content: PATERSON, N.J. — When Bob Kendrick visited Hinchliffe Stadium in 2014, all he could do was hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Can You Spot the Dog Hidden in This Picasso Painting?
description: Recent imaging and restoration of Pablo Picasso’s “Le Moulin de la Galette” revealed a dog that had been painted over.
content: In Pablo Picasso’s 1900 painting “Le Moulin de la Galette,” revelers sporting dresses or top hats appear to be drinking, dancing and chatting. Beneath the partyers, under layers of paint, there is a hidden dog that the artist seems to have hastily painted over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: In Florida Upset, Democrat Wins Jacksonville Mayor’s Race
description: Donna Deegan is only the second Democrat to be elected mayor of Florida’s biggest city in the past three decades.
content: MIAMI — Donna Deegan, a Democrat, was elected mayor of Jacksonville on Tuesday, shaking up the politics of Florida’s largest city, where Republican mayors have been in power for all but four of the last 30 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: N.B.A. Commissioner ‘Shocked’ by New Morant Video With Apparent Gun
description: Ja Morant, the Memphis Grizzlies guard, apologized Tuesday after days of backlash for a video that appeared to show him brandishing a gun for the second time.
content: The star Memphis Grizzlies guard Ja Morant apologized late Tuesday after receiving days of backlash for a social media video that appeared to show him brandishing a gun in public for the second time in just over two months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arielle Paul
title: Burning Man Becomes Latest Adversary in Geothermal Feud
description: Festival organizers are trying to block plans to build a clean energy plant in the Nevada desert, highlighting the struggle to combat climate change and the cost of clean power.
content: One of the darkest towns in America lies roughly 100 miles north of Reno, where the lights are few and rarely lit until one week each summer when pyrotechnics and LEDs set the sky and mountains aglow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: reverie
description: This word has appeared in 57 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word reverie has appeared in 57 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 20 in the book review “The Sound of Sonny” by Ben Ratliff:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: New Hampshire Honored a ‘Rebel Girl.’ Then It Found Out She Was a Communist.
description: A historical marker honoring the labor leader and feminist Elizabeth Gurley Flynn in her birthplace of Concord, N.H., was taken down after Republican lawmakers called the Communist activist “anti-American.”
content: From a young age, the activist Elizabeth Gurley Flynn was known to embrace an agenda that espoused workers’ and women’s rights. Ms. Flynn gave her first political speech in 1906, when she was 15, and went on to become a founder of the American Civil Liberties Union, an organizer at the Industrial Workers of the World union and, eventually, a leader of the Communist Party of the United States. Her bold actions earned her the nickname “Rebel Girl.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Jones
title: This Spider Is Imperfect, and That May Be the Secret of Its Survival
description: A colorful jumping spider mimics multiple species of ants, and its repertoire of impressions seems to help it scare off one of its fiercest predators.
content: Siler collingwoodi is a spider that jumps and wears a coat of vibrant and metallic blues, oranges and sometimes reds. It also does impressions, copying the movements of an assortment of ant species.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Operator of Limo Service Is Convicted in 2018 Accident That Killed 20
description: The operator, Nauman Hussain, could face up to 15 years in prison for the tragic crash in Schoharie, N.Y.
content: SCHOHARIE, N.Y. — It was a staggering and seemingly incomprehensible tragedy: a Saturday afternoon limo ride gone terribly wrong, leaving 20 people dead, including a large group of young friends and relatives headed to a birthday party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Gulsin Harman
title: Ukraine and Russia Renew a Deal to Allow Ukraine to Ship Grain
description: Russia last year blocked exports of Ukrainian grain across the Black Sea, a vital part of the global food supply, but they resumed last summer under a fragile pact.
content: Ukraine and Russia agreed Wednesday to a two-month extension of a wartime deal that allows Ukraine to ship its grain across the Black Sea, a rare example of cooperation between the two countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Study Offers New Twist in How the First Humans Evolved
description: A new genetic analysis of 290 people suggests that humans emerged at various times and places in Africa.
content: Scientists have revealed a surprisingly complex origin of our species, rejecting the long-held argument that modern humans arose from one place in Africa during one period in time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: For Biden, Crisis at Home Complicates Diplomacy Abroad
description: Volatility has become the new norm in Washington as the president heads to Japan, where he will reassure world leaders that the debt ceiling showdown will not upend the global economy.
content: President Biden left for Japan on Wednesday for a meeting of the leaders of seven major industrial democracies who get together each year to try to keep the world economy stable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Sign Up for Well’s 5-Week Walking Series
description: We’ll share tips and inspiration to help you get moving this June.
content: I’m an enthusiastic walker. I stroll to straighten up my back when I’ve been hunched over a computer for too long. If I get some good news, I take a few laps around my neighborhood to savor it. I walk with my teen to prompt her to open up to me. And it’s probably no surprise that many of us at Well conduct meetings while on foot. So we’re dedicating the entire month of June to exploring the joy of walking — and I hope you’ll come along with us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Brie Larson Did Watch ‘Jeanne du Barry’ at Cannes
description: On Day 1 of the festival, the juror who was active in Hollywood’s #MeToo response was asked if she would view the Johnny Depp film. She answered tersely.
content: As the president of this year’s competition jury at the Cannes Film Festival, the director Ruben Ostlund had one key piece of wisdom to impart to his fellow jurors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu and Paul Mozur
title: As China Looms Over Taiwan’s Presidential Race, the Opposition Picks a Moderate
description: The Kuomintang nominated Hou Yu-ih, a popular mayor who has said little about geopolitical issues, as the party tries to appeal to voters wary of Beijing.
content: Once a dominant political force, Taiwan’s main opposition party lost the last two presidential elections in large part because it has promoted closer ties with China. Now, faced with voters who have been alarmed by Beijing’s aggression toward the island, the Kuomintang is placing its hopes on a new type of candidate: a popular local leader with a blank slate on the thorny question of China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
title: The Latest Rift Among Ukraine’s Allies Is Whether to Send F-16s
description: The United States is resisting a European push for the powerful fighters. But will it relent, as it did before with tanks, rocket launchers and air defense missiles?
content: A fresh push by Britain and the Netherlands to provide Ukraine with F-16 fighter planes has exposed the latest fault line among Western allies who have wrangled repeatedly over sending powerful weapons of war, once again pitting a reluctant United States against some of its closest European partners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: That’s the Funny Thing About Grief
description: A new generation of stand-ups is mining the heartbreaking loss of a loved one for ambitious shows. How did we get here?
content: Denial. Anger. Bargaining. Depression. Stand-up comedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: There’s No Escape From Wildfire Smoke
description: Even distant fires can send dangerous, imperceptible pollution to your doorstep.
content: In Western Canada, fire season comes early by American standards — beginning, usually, right around now. In Alberta, by today’s date, only about 1,000 acres have burned in recent years. This season so far, the total is already more than 1.5 million — which would make it the province’s third-worst annual result, just a few weeks into May, with months more of wildfire season still to burn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Lawyer Resigns From Defense Team in Special Counsel Inquiries
description: Timothy Parlatore, who has been defending the former president in the investigations into classified documents and Jan. 6, is leaving as federal prosecutors appear to be nearing decisions about bringing charges.
content: Timothy Parlatore, one of the lawyers representing former President Donald J. Trump in the federal investigations into Mr. Trump’s handling of classified documents and his efforts to overturn the 2020 election, has resigned from the former president’s legal team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: The G7 Begins
description: Also, hot years ahead as global temperatures rise.
content: The annual Group of 7 summit opens today in Hiroshima, Japan, where the leaders of the seven major industrial democracies will discuss how to keep the global economy stable. They will also focus on shoring up diplomatic relations at a time of great global uncertainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Celtics Tickets, Political Revenge: U.S. Attorney Accused of Broad Misconduct
description: Rachael S. Rollins, who plans to resign from her office in Boston, tried to aid a political ally, lied under oath and violated the Hatch Act, a pair of government watchdog reports found.
content: The U.S. attorney for Massachusetts, Rachael S. Rollins, misused her office to “boost” a political ally, flouted ethics rules to obtain free tickets from the Boston Celtics and lied under oath to investigators, the Justice Department inspector general said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: The Nuggets Want You to Forget What You Heard About the Nuggets
description: Denver is unraveling its reputation for playoff disappointment one win at a time.
content: The Denver Nuggets have spent the past few months hearing that they weren’t to be trusted in the playoffs, that Nikola Jokic, a two-time most valuable player, couldn’t lead them to postseason success, that their record, the best in the Western Conference for most of the season, was some kind of mirage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Push for Reparations at Dodger Stadium
description: A conversation with the New York Times reporter Jesus Jiménez about an effort by Los Angeles activists to reclaim the land under the ballpark.
content: The Los Angeles Dodgers have one of the largest Latino fan bases in Major League Baseball — a reflection of Los Angeles’s population, but also of the team’s active recruitment of Latino fans over the past half-century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: 10 Ideas for Reflecting at the End of the School Year
description: Inspired by Times articles and features from across sections, these exercises can help both students and teachers think about their growth.
content: Last fall we began the school year with 10 ideas for building community, all of which were inspired by Times features. Now, as the academic year comes to a close, we’re making another list, one both teachers and students can use — ideally working together. Below, 10 ways to reflect on the year that was, think about what you learned, note how you grew and changed — and consider what it all means for next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: A Queer Punk Vaudevillian’s Surreal Take on ‘Titanic’
description: Jibz Cameron, who performs as Dynasty Handbag, is bringing a new multimedia performance to Brooklyn. It might be more epic than the blockbuster movie.
content: In some ways, turning the movie “Titanic” into a farce about climate change makes a lot of narrative sense. Instead of an iceberg — which has melted, of course — the ship goes down because it hits a mountain of underwater garbage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Says He Is Confident America Will Not Default on Its Debts
description: Speaking just moments before he left for a diplomatic trip overseas, President Biden said a default would be “catastrophic.”
content: President Biden, just moments before he departed on Wednesday for a diplomatic trip to Asia, said he was confident “America will not default” as congressional leaders in both parties offered some signs of optimism about eventually reaching a deal to raise the nation’s borrowing limit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadia Marzouki
title: My Country Was a Dictatorship Before. This Feels Worse.
description: What’s happening to Tunisia is a tragedy.
content: I remember exactly when I knew that Tunisia was free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Nicole Holofcener on the Absurdity of Everyday Life
description: The star and director share a sensibility that comes through in their new film, “You Hurt My Feelings,” about a small thing that rocks a marriage.
content: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Sisters from another mister. Cinematic alter egos. However you define it, Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Nicole Holofcener have a connection that rivals the great movie partnerships of our time. New York transplants who are similar in height and in age, Louis-Dreyfus, 62, and Holofcener, 63, each have two grown sons, a healthy self-deprecating attitude and the ability to riff on any topic: cake (it’s their favorite dessert), Hollywood gossip (yes, Robert De Niro did just have a baby) and the indignities of aging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Dress Your Greens With Chicken and Olives
description: Garlicky, vinegary pan juices form a flavorful dressing for kale and olives in this easy sheet-pan dinner.
content: One of my favorite dinner shortcuts is to nestle a hot roast chicken on a heap of sturdy greens like kale, baby mustard or watercress. The chicken fat coats and gently wilts the greens, infusing them with the chicken’s flavor. It’s a perfect side dish for the roasted bird that requires no extra work.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Drug Shortages Spur Rationing to Critically Ill
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 17, 2023.
content: “Our patients are in a war, and what we’re doing is we’re taking their weapons away.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
title: Gains Near Bakhmut Raise Ukraine’s Hopes of a Turning Tide
description: The advances have been small, and Russians still hold most of the city, but Ukrainians say they see a meaningful shift in momentum.
content: Russian forces spent nearly a year carving a path of devastation and death in their bid to surround the city of Bakhmut in eastern Ukraine, and by March it seemed they were close to succeeding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Robert E. Lucas Jr., Nobel-Winning Conservative Economist, Dies at 85
description: Challenging the theories of John Maynard Keynes, he questioned the idea that government intervention could help steer the economy.
content: Robert E. Lucas Jr., a contrarian Nobel laureate in economics who undergirded conservative arguments that government intervention in fiscal policy is often self-defeating, died on Monday in Chicago. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: For Gen Z, Playing an Influencer on TikTok Comes Naturally
description: There’s stuff to promote now. The followers can come later.
content: Rachel Aaron, a 24-year-old who works in public relations in New York, recently dressed up for a work event at Bloomingdale’s. In the era of “get ready with me” videos on TikTok, it was a golden opportunity to create content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: The Liberty Took a Few Jets and a Boat to Become a Superteam
description: Clara Wu Tsai and Joe Tsai, the Liberty owners, improved their facilities and chartered flights, drawing a W.N.B.A. fine — and enticing top free agents.
content: In January, Clara Wu Tsai flew to Turkey on a trip that altered the balance of power in the W.N.B.A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew McCarthy
title: Andrew McCarthy Wrote a Book About a Father-Son Pilgrimage. His Son Gets His Say.
description: Sam McCarthy accompanied his father on the Camino de Santiago and is featured in his father’s new memoir, but what did he think of it? The pair discuss their achievement.
content: In the ninth century, the Catholic Church announced that the remains of the apostle James had been discovered in the far western reach of the Iberian Peninsula, at what would become the town of Santiago de Compostela. It further declared that anyone willing to make a pilgrimage to the spot would receive plenary indulgences, or the remission of punishment for their sins. The faithful came running, er, walking. The Camino de Santiago sprang into existence and has been traversed, with varying degrees of popularity, ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Rachelle Bonja, Michael Simon Johnson, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Lisa Chow, Rachel Quester, Diane Wong, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Turkey’s President Fights for Political Survival
description: What does the country’s first ever runoff election say about the state of its democracy?
content: For two decades, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has loomed large over Turkish politics. But skyrocketing inflation and a devastating earthquake have eroded his power and, in a presidential election over the weekend, he was forced into a runoff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priyanka Runwal
title: Desert Monoliths Reveal World’s Oldest Architectural Plans
description: Engravings found in Jordan and Saudi Arabia appeared to match nearby ancient megastructures known as desert kites as seen from above.
content: Massive prehistoric stone structures found in desert landscapes from Saudi Arabia to Kazakhstan have baffled archaeologists for decades. Each can stretch for up to a few miles, and resembles a kite with tail strings in overall shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Won’t Block Illinois Laws on High-Powered Rifles
description: The justices struck down a New York gun control law last year, announcing a new test to evaluate the constitutionality of such measures.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday refused to block two Illinois laws prohibiting the sale of high-powered guns and high-capacity magazines while challenges to them move forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Haven’t Checked Your Gmail in a While? Google May Delete Your Account.
description: Personal Google accounts that have not been used in at least two years could be removed starting in December as part of an effort to address security threats, the company said.
content: Starting in December, Google will begin deleting accounts that have not been used in at least two years as part of an effort to address security risks, the company said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Widmer
title: How an Unconventional Approach to Religion Helped Shape a Divided Nation
description: In “Lincoln’s God,” Joshua Zeitz examines the 16th president’s personal and idiosyncratic brand of Christianity.
content: Anyone who has enjoyed the privilege of examining the Lincoln Bible — on which three presidents to date have taken their oaths of office, including Abraham Lincoln — will know that the pages are immaculate, as if never opened and read. In fact, Lincoln borrowed the book from a Supreme Court clerk for his 1861 swearing-in at the last minute, and the detail is telling, in keeping with Lincoln’s considerable distance from organized religion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Oldest Nearly Complete Hebrew Bible Sells for $38.1 Million
description: The Codex Sassoon, believed to date from the late 9th or early 10th century, was bought at Sotheby’s by the American Friends of the ANU — Museum of the Jewish People.
content: The oldest near-complete Hebrew Bible sold at Sotheby’s for $38.1 million on Wednesday, one of the highest prices for a book or historical document ever sold at auction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: The Composer Carlos Simon Is Busier, and More Honest, Than Ever
description: On the rise before the pandemic, Simon has shot to even greater prominence since. His next premiere commemorates the murder of George Floyd.
content: The composer Carlos Simon is busy. Six premieres in four months busy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Plan to Build a New Capital
description: Jakarta is sinking, and Indonesia’s president has chosen to move the capital. The Times accompanied him on a tour.
content: “Jakarta has a lot of problems,” says my colleague Hannah Beech, The Times’s senior correspondent for Asia, “but its most existential one is that it is sinking in some places by up to a foot a year.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus J. Moore
title: Kassa Overall Knows Artists Feel Pressure. His New Album Explores It.
description: The drummer whose genre-crossing work has brought acclaim here and abroad returns with “Animals,” an LP of jazz, rap and soul inspired by the struggle to be OK.
content: On a cloudy afternoon, the drummer Kassa Overall strolled past his first New York City apartment, a second-floor room in a Fort Greene brownstone. He had moved to Brooklyn after graduating from Oberlin in 2006 to play in the local jazz scene while improving his chops as a beatmaker. To help him make ends meet, the drummer Billy Hart got him a gig playing the djembe for a physical therapy dance class at a nursing home in Harlem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: Pale Male, the Famous Central Park Hawk, Is Dead at 32. Maybe.
description: Some believe that a sickly red-tailed hawk found in New York City was the same bird that stole the national spotlight in 2004. Others disagree.
content: Pale Male, a red-tailed hawk who took up residence on the ledge of a ritzy Manhattan apartment building 30 years ago, became the subject of hundreds of newspaper articles, at least three books and an award-winning documentary film and counted Mary Tyler Moore among his fans, was pronounced dead on Tuesday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: House Republicans Stall Effort to Kick George Santos Out of Congress
description: Democrats tried to force a vote to expel Mr. Santos, a Republican of New York who was indicted last week. But Republicans pushed the matter to the House Ethics Committee.
content: House Republicans on Wednesday repelled an effort by Democrats to force a vote on expelling Representative George Santos of New York, who was charged last week in a 13-count federal indictment covering wire fraud, unlawful monetary transactions, stealing public funds and lying on financial disclosures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Better Shrimp Cocktail Is Closer Than You Think
description: Do as Melissa Clark does, and roast, don’t poach, the shrimp, then serve them with a creamy horseradish rémoulade.
content: The best advice for making shrimp cocktail I ever learned came from the great chef and cookbook author James Beard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: They Watched Jordan Neely Die. Did They Have a Duty to Intervene?
description: New York does not require bystanders to act when someone is in danger, but the killing on the F train has residents debating when they should step in.
content: As Jordan Neely struggled to free himself from a chokehold in the New York City subway earlier this month, there were the passengers who pinned him down and the passengers who watched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius, Mark Landler, Hurubie Meko and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Prince Harry and Meghan Say They Were Chased by Paparazzi in New York
description: The initial description of the episode in Midtown Manhattan recalled the chase that killed Harry’s mother, but the fuller picture was more complicated.
content: The statement was alarming, unmistakably evocative of the car chase that killed Princess Diana 26 years ago: Prince Harry and his wife Meghan had been “involved in a near catastrophic car chase at the hands of a ring of highly aggressive paparazzi,” according to an unnamed spokesperson for the couple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: Syria’s Assad to Attend Arab League Summit After Yearslong Suspension
description: President Bashar al-Assad is expected to participate in the meeting for the first time since brutally crushing his country’s Arab Spring uprising.
content: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria plans to attend a gathering of Arab leaders on Friday for the first time since he violently suppressed an anti-government uprising that morphed into a civil war, torturing and using chemical weapons on his own people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Kusama Takes On the Infinite With a Sly Wink
description: The Japanese artist’s new exhibition in Manhattan includes undulating pumpkins and graphic paintings, but her latest Infinity Mirror Room is the star of the show.
content: Once a high-profile fixture of the 1960s New York avant-garde, Yayoi Kusama has long since become an icon, in the sense of a visually recognizable brand. Her polka dots, her spectacular sculptures of flowers and pumpkins, and most of all her “Infinity Mirror Rooms,” which regularly draw crowds willing to wait hours for as little as one minute inside — it’s all as familiar, and as reliably perfect, as Coca-Cola. Like Coca-Cola, it also goes with anything: A recent collaboration with Louis Vuitton even included Instagram and Snapchat filters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Killing on the Subway: Outrage, Fear, Empathy
description: Readers discuss the arrest of Daniel Penny for killing a mentally ill man and their fears about riding on the subway. Also: Democrats as a working-class party.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: 17 Summer Recipes Our Food Staff Can’t Wait to Make
description: Mentally, we’re in July.
content: Summer can be a punishing time of year — the heat! — but it can also be the most rewarding, full of juicy stone fruit consumed precariously over the kitchen sink, plump tomatoes fresh from the market (or the garden, if you’re lucky) and impromptu beach days that call for recipes both simple and satisfying. The season also flies by. In hopes of slowing down these warmer months and savoring every delicious bite of what summer has to offer, here are 17 recipes the New York Times Food staff can’t wait to make.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: With Stakes at Their Highest, Manchester City Rises Higher Still
description: City defeated Real Madrid, 4-0, in the second leg of their Champions League semifinal to take another step toward the prize it has long sought.
content: MANCHESTER, England — No matter what happens from here, regardless of whether Manchester City’s campaign in the Champions League ends with medals and parades and the realization of the club’s ultimate, meticulously planned dream, it felt as if something shifted amid the delirious tumult of the Etihad Stadium on Wednesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: America Has Become Both More and Less Dangerous Since Black Lives Matter
description: Black Lives Matter protests reduce police violence. Homicides have risen. How do we make sense of it all?
content: A couple of years ago, Travis Campbell, an economics professor at Southern Oregon University, published a study showing that from 2014 to 2019, Black Lives Matter protests “meaningfully reduced” police homicides. Those years saw urban protests prompted by the Aug. 9, 2014, shooting death of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., and the April 12, 2015, death in police custody of Freddie Gray in Baltimore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Meet the Pro Athlete Who Is Thrilled to Be in His 50s
description: Steven Alker’s golf career was largely unremarkable. Then he joined the senior circuit and won so big that he’ll play his debut P.G.A. Championship.
content: THE WOODLANDS, Texas — Just past a Dairy Queen near Houston last month, Steven Alker’s new status was aloft: His name and face were on a lamppost banner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Sounds of Recognition
description: Parker Higgins breaks things down for us.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Coming to America
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Canada’s Wildfires Have Been Disrupting Lives. Now, Oil and Gas Take a Hit.
description: Alberta’s vast oil industry is cutting production as the flames menace wells and pipelines, highlighting the danger
content: Wildfires sweeping across western Canada that have driven thousands of people from their homes are also striking the heart of Canadian oil and gas country, forcing companies to curb production.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jessie Ware Is Dancing Into Her Second Act
description: A conversation about the British musician’s journey to her lush neo-disco manifesto “That! Feels Good!”
content: The fifth Jessie Ware album, “That! Feels Good!,” is a robust, richly sung neo-disco manifesto, among the most vibrant music the singer has released. It marks a solidification of Ware’s second phase, following her early years making restrained club-soul and adult-contemporary R&B.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: After Historic Primary in Philadelphia, a New Mayor Will Face Old Problems
description: Cherelle Parker’s win in the Democratic primary is a sign of how the city has changed. But Philadelphia’s challenges remain deep and daunting.
content: PHILADELPHIA — The afternoon before Election Day, Jennifer Robinson, 41, was trying to manage her two small children in the quiet corner of a public library in a pocket of her city that had endured generations of abandonment. She was despondent about the state of Philadelphia, most of all about the crime, but she talked about the mayoral primary as if it had little bearing on any of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Firestone
title: How to Use the Debt Ceiling to Inflict Cruelty on the Poor
description: Republicans have singled out low-income Americans, yet again, as a prime target in this year’s scheme over the debt limit.
content: Seen from outside Washington, the debt ceiling battle might seem like an abstract argument between the political parties over federal spending and deficits. But for millions of low-income Americans who depend on the federal government for health care and basic nutrition, the debate is about their very lives. That’s because Republicans have singled them out, yet again, as a prime target in this year’s extortion scheme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Why Prosecutors Waited Before They Charged Daniel Penny
description: After the ruling that Jordan Neely’s death on a subway train was a homicide, the Manhattan district attorney’s office faced several choices over how to charge his killer.
content: The killing of a 30-year-old homeless Black man by a white rider on a New York City subway car has prompted intense debate over the response by the police and prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: How Did You Grow and Change This School Year?
description: In this forum, we invite both students and teachers to reflect on their challenges and successes — and to consider how to build on them for next year.
content: The 2022-23 academic year is coming to a close, and we’ve created a post describing 10 ways to reflect on these last months and learn from them. But the 10 ways aren’t just for students — we also hope teachers can benefit from them. In fact, we would be delighted if teachers and students did some of the exercises together and told us what happened!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: House Democrats Move Forward With Petition to Force Debt Limit Vote
description: The initiation of a discharge petition is seen as a last resort for averting default if negotiations over raising the debt ceiling collapse, and a way to pressure Republicans to strike a deal.
content: House Democrats pushed forward on Wednesday with a procedural move that could force a vote to increase the debt limit should negotiations between President Biden and Republicans collapse, moving despite signs of progress in the bipartisan talks to advance a long-shot Plan B to avert a default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Drug Shortages Near an All-Time High, Leading to Rationing
description: A worrisome scarcity of cancer drugs has heightened concerns about the troubled generic drug industry. Congress and the White House are seeking ways to address widespread supply problems.
content: Thousands of patients are facing delays in getting treatments for cancer and other life-threatening diseases, with drug shortages in the United States approaching record levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Bizarre Sea Creatures Illuminate the Dawn of the Animal Kingdom
description: A new study bolsters the idea that the first animals were surprisingly complex, perhaps equipped with muscles and a nervous system.
content: One of the greatest transformations in the history of life occurred more than 600 million years ago, when a single-celled organism gave rise to the first animals. With their multicellular bodies, animals evolved into a staggering range of forms, like whales that weigh 200 tons, birds that soar six miles into the sky and sidewinders that slither across desert dunes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: She Smoked Weed, Legally, Then Gave Birth. New York Took Her Baby.
description: The city’s child welfare agency is not supposed to remove children solely because of a parent’s marijuana use. A mother says the agency did so anyway, and now she is suing.
content: For Chanetto Rivers, the birth of her third child went relatively smoothly. About an hour after she arrived at the hospital in the Bronx, she was holding her newborn son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Trounced, Conservatives Feel Voters’ Wrath in English Heartlands
description: Defections in the once solidly Conservative southern “blue wall” drove large losses in recent municipal elections.
content: LITTLEWICK GREEN, England — Aged 22 and not long out of college, George Blundell never expected to win when he ran in municipal elections against a Conservative Party bigwig in a region long loyal to the Tories. But for a young, enthusiastic, former politics student it still seemed worth a shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Cable News Viewers Aren’t as Extreme as You Might Think
description: They’re younger and less partisan than stereotypes suggest.
content: The stereotype of a Fox News viewer is well established: It’s a retired conservative white guy who probably lives in the Midwest or South — what might be called “real America,” either mawkishly or sneeringly, depending on your point of view. The stereotype of an MSNBC viewer is similarly well established: An older, Prius-driving coastal liberal who turns on “Morning Joe” when she wakes up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: After Years of Political Hype, the Durham Inquiry Failed to Deliver
description: A dysfunctional investigation led by a Trump-era special counsel illustrates a dilemma about prosecutorial independence and accountability in politically sensitive matters.
content: The limping conclusion to John H. Durham’s four-year investigation of the Russia inquiry underscores a recurring dilemma in American government: how to shield sensitive law enforcement investigations from politics without creating prosecutors who can run amok, never to be held to account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: The Secret to Mastering Your Cocktail Order
description: Over time, one thing becomes clear: When it comes to finding your drink, the devil is often in the details.
content: “Double Scotch, single-malt.” I tried my best to get the words out confidently, hoping to channel Patrick Dempsey’s character, Dr. McDreamy, on “Grey’s Anatomy.” If a three-ounce pour of single-malt Scotch whisky was good enough for a suave television neurosurgeon, then it was good enough for me, a squeaky 19-year-old with his big brother’s ID at a Manhattan dive bar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Two Television Showrunners on ‘Creative Short Circuits’
description: Soo Hugh (“Pachinko”) and Damon Lindelof (“Lost,” “Mrs. Davis”) discuss learning from their staffs, wanting to hear “no” and navigating the writers’ strike.
content: Years ago, the television writer Soo Hugh had a meeting with Damon Lindelof, one of the creators of the groundbreaking ABC drama “Lost.” Lindelof was looking for writers to work on his next series, “The Leftovers,” for HBO, and Hugh was an admirer. She didn’t get the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder, Lauren Hirsch and Kevin Draper
title: Mickelson Among Players Interviewed in Antitrust Inquiry Into Pro Golf
description: The Justice Department met with PGA Tour lawyers this week, but a timeline for the completion of its review is unclear.
content: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — The Justice Department’s antitrust inquiry into men’s professional golf has included interviews with players, including the major tournament winners Phil Mickelson, Bryson DeChambeau and Sergio García, as the authorities examine whether the PGA Tour sought to manipulate the sport’s labor market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: ‘King James’ Review: We’ll Always Have LeBron
description: Two men’s kindred obsession with a basketball player is the scaffold for Rajiv Joseph’s examination of male friendship at the Manhattan Theater Club.
content: It takes a while to figure out if Rajiv Joseph’s latest play, “King James” — centered on two fans of the N.B.A. legend LeBron James — is actually about basketball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Idaho Murders Suspect Is Indicted by Grand Jury
description: Instead of facing a preliminary hearing, the Ph.D. student accused of killing four University of Idaho students will be arraigned on murder charges next week.
content: The man accused of fatally stabbing four University of Idaho students last year has been indicted by a grand jury and will be arraigned on murder charges next week, a court spokesman said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Why Ted Lasso’s Shoe Game Is So Strong
description: Credit the show’s star and creator, Jason Sudeikis, a real-life sneakerhead who owns about 250 pairs.
content: There’s a reason that Ted Lasso, the fictional, sunny, mustachioed American hired to manage an English football club in the Apple TV+ series of the same name, is a sneakerhead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: ‘Catastrophic’ Floods in Italy Leave 8 Dead and Thousands Homeless
description: Intense downpours caused rivers to overflow in the northern region of Emilia-Romagna, swamping numerous cities in a catastrophe that experts described as “unprecedented.”
content: Widespread flooding in the northern Italian region of Emilia-Romagna killed at least eight people and forced another 5,000 to abandon their homes, officials said on Wednesday as rescue efforts continued to assist those stuck on the upper stories of buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Rust’ Prosecutors Seek Further Tests on Gun Handled by Alec Baldwin
description: The prosecutors, who dropped criminal charges against Mr. Baldwin after learning that the gun he was rehearsing with might have been modified, are sending the gun to a forensic specialist.
content: Prosecutors are seeking further testing on the gun that Alec Baldwin was handling on the “Rust” film set when it fired and killed the cinematographer Halyna Hutchins, as they work to decide whether to revive a criminal case against the actor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $325,000 Homes in Georgia, Maryland and Arkansas
description: A Victorian home in Waynesboro, a rowhouse in Baltimore and a cottage in Little Rock.
content: This house is on one of Waynesboro’s main streets, a few blocks from the center of town and within walking distance of City Hall, antiques shops and casual restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: The Essential Neil Gaiman
description: The man behind the landmark reboot of “The Sandman” comic (and Netflix series) is going strong after decades of writing in just about every format. Here’s where to get started with his books for adults.
content: In his stories of horror, humanity and uncomfortable truths, Neil Gaiman is never afraid to go into dark places looking for the light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: How Oak Hill Was Returned to Its Roots
description: The course near Rochester, N.Y., will host the P.G.A. Championship for the first time in a decade. In the interim, a restoration took place to bring the course back toward Donald J. Ross’s original design.
content: Oak Hill Country Club, near Rochester, N.Y., has been a familiar stop for men’s professional golf for decades: Since 1956, it has hosted three U.S. Opens, three P.G.A. Championships and a Ryder Cup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
title: He Lost Turkey’s Presidential Election, but Could Swing the Runoff
description: Seen by some as spoiler but by others as a kingmaker, Sinan Ogan, the far-right candidate who came in third in the vote, says he is being courted by the two finalists: the sitting president and his challenger.
content: ANKARA — As Sinan Ogan tells it, he has suddenly become the most sought-after man in Turkey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elise Loehnen
title: The Lies Mothers Tell Themselves and Their Children
description: You can love your kids deeply and hate being a mom.
content: I learned I wasn’t wanted during a party game. One Christmas, home from college, I went to a holiday gathering of families with my parents. After dinner we played a game in which husbands answered frank questions on behalf of their wives. When my parents’ turn came, the host asked my father, “How many children did you want when you got married?” My dad, ventriloquizing my mother, snapped, “Zero. Definitely zero.” She nodded along, unfazed, as everyone in the room laughed uneasily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Héctor Tobar
title: Read Your Way Around Los Angeles
description: Héctor Tobar is a son of Los Angeles, a city of “perpetual cultural mixing.” Here, he guides readers through the books and writers that cut through the city’s layers.
content: On Sunset Boulevard in Bel Air, street vendors offer “Maps to the Stars’ Homes.” The vendors don’t sell “Maps to the Authors’ Homes,” which is a shame, because F. Scott Fitzgerald, Tennessee Williams and Truman Capote all lived nearby. A map to the homes of Angeleno authors might also guide you to the bungalow where Bertolt Brecht penned one of his greatest plays, “The Caucasian Chalk Circle.” And to the mansion where a teenager named Susan Sontag visited one of her literary heroes, the German exile and Nobel laureate Thomas Mann.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Johnny Depp at Cannes: ‘I Don’t Have Much Further Need for Hollywood’
description: At a news conference, the controversial star of the opening-night film used McDonald’s metaphors to answer questions about how he is viewed.
content: CANNES, France — At first, you had to wonder if they were running out the clock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Our Theater is Fighting About Diversity. Who’s Right?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to cast an upcoming rendition of “Fiddler on the Roof.”
content: I am involved with a well-regarded community theater that has made significant efforts to diversify its membership, casts and audience. A conflict has arisen over a proposed production of “Fiddler on the Roof.” (Yes, we know, “Fiddler” has been done to death in community theaters. A different issue.) The director proposing the production has committed himself to colorblind casting. Others involved say that, in view of the Jewish community the play is about, they would consider this to be a cultural appropriation. How should we approach this conflict in values? — Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Young Adult Novels to China’s Cultural Revolution
description: A selection of recently published books.
content: WARRIOR GIRL UNEARTHED, by Angeline Boulley. (Holt, $19.99.) Boulley’s latest Y.A. novel returns to the world of her best-selling debut, “Firekeeper’s Daughter,” this time following an Indigenous teenager who coordinates a heist to recover the stolen remains of her ancestors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Queenmaker’ Review: Society Blogger to Self-Made Celebrity
description: The chronicler of the post-9/11 New York social whirl who is at the center of this documentary was no Manhattan insider but rather a student in Illinois.
content: This frequently startling documentary begins with some fairly banal observations about the nature of a contemporary sickness. In jaded tones, a female voice-over says, “After years of worshiping monarchs and majesty, we now worship the celebrity.” What follows for the next 20 minutes or so of “Queenmaker: The Making of an It Girl” constitutes a fast-paced account of the ascendancy of famous-for-being-famous rich kids — the Hilton sisters, the Miller sisters, Amanda Hearst, Olivia Palermo, Casey Johnson. The publicist Kelly Cutrone, describing New York nightlife in the late ’90s and early aughts, remembers, “People were doing blow and they were hanging out and they were making the world go ’round.” ’Twas ever thus, one supposes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Loudin
title: Tennis Elbow is a Real Pain. Here’s How to Treat It.
description: The painful condition isn’t just caused by racket swings, and can sideline you from activity. But a few simple tips can get you back into the game.
content: Now that warm weather is here to stay, many Americans are getting back into their favorite outdoor sports and starting home projects. Which means, among other things, the annual uptick in tennis elbow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: ‘Digital Twin’ of the Titanic Shows the Shipwreck in Stunning Detail
description: Researchers hope new 3-D images will provide clues about what happened to the ocean liner when it sank on its maiden voyage in 1912.
content: An ambitious digital imaging project has produced what researchers describe as a “digital twin” of the R.M.S. Titanic, showing the wreckage of the doomed ocean liner with a level of detail that has never been captured before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Montana Governor Signs Total Ban of TikTok in the State
description: The legislation is the most extreme prohibition of the app in the nation and will almost certainly face legal challenges.
content: The governor of Montana, Greg Gianforte, signed a bill on Wednesday to ban TikTok from operating inside the state, the most extreme prohibition of the app in the nation and one that will almost certainly be challenged in court. The ban will take effect on Jan. 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Legalizing Marijuana Is a Big Mistake
description: The experiment so far is vindicating the prohibitionists.
content: Of all the ways to win a culture war, the smoothest is to just make the other side seem hopelessly uncool. So it’s been with the march of marijuana legalization: There have been moral arguments about the excesses of the drug war and medical arguments about the potential benefits of pot, but the vibe of the whole debate has pitted the chill against the uptight, the cool against the square, the relaxed future against the Principal Skinners of the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Brooklyn’s Batcave Reborn as Gotham’s Art Factory
description: A philanthropist spent $180 million to transform a relic of Gowanus’s industrial past into Powerhouse Arts, equipped to produce the art of the future.
content: Rising at the edge of Brooklyn’s Gowanus Canal — a rezoned superfund site with developers racing to build — the colossal industrial relic known locally as the Batcave has found its own Bruce Wayne.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: San Antonio Spurs Get the No. 1 Pick in the N.B.A. Draft Lottery
description: The top pick is widely expected to be Victor Wembanyama, a 19-year-old French basketball star.
content: The San Antonio Spurs won the 2023 N.B.A. draft lottery on Tuesday, giving them the No. 1 pick in June’s draft and the right to select the most anticipated prospect since LeBron James: the 19-year-old French star Victor Wembanyama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: E.P.A. Announces Crackdown on Toxic Coal Ash From Landfills
description: Hundreds of landfills containing toxic coal ash have gone unregulated for years, posing hazards to human health and the environment.
content: The Biden administration is moving to close a loophole that had exempted hundreds of inactive coal ash landfills from rules designed to prevent heavy metals like mercury and arsenic from seeping into groundwater, the Environmental Protection Agency said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jedediah Britton-Purdy
title: The Courts Should Be More Political, Not Less
description: Urging more politicization may seem perverse. But in some states, it’s the only way to strengthen our democracy and empower voters.
content: DURHAM, N.C. — The details are all too familiar: Last fall, an election in North Carolina flipped the balance of the State Supreme Court from Democrats to Republicans, and in less than six months, the new conservative majority had reversed a decision from last December and ruled that the legislature can gerrymander election maps with no constitutional limit. Another episode of political hardball. Another example of Republicans pushing institutions to their limits to keep power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Shane Goldmacher
title: DeSantis Goes 0-for-2 on Election Night
description: The 2024 hopeful made a dramatic, election-eve show of support in the Kentucky governor’s race, only for his chosen candidate to get clobbered. Another favored candidate in Jacksonville, Fla., lost, too.
content: On Monday, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida went out on a limb. On Tuesday, it snapped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: French Resistance Fighter Goes Public About Execution of German P.O.W.s
description: Forty-seven soldiers were shot dead and secretly buried shortly after D-Day, a veteran says. The story was hidden for decades.
content: Shortly after D-Day during World War II, French resistance fighters took 47 captured German soldiers to a small wooden area in southwest-central France. In the scorching heat, they forced the soldiers to dig their own graves, shot them dead one by one and buried the bodies, covering the remains with quicklime, according to a witness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Covid Emergency Is Over. Covid’s Still Here.
description: The crisis phase of the pandemic is officially finished, and Covid-related health care entitlements will change.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. It’s been almost a week since the end of the coronavirus health emergency. We’ll look at what that has meant for New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Jones
title: How Do You Actually Help a Suicidal Teen?
description: It’s a dark time for therapists treating adolescents in despair. But some things do work.
content: Early one morning last year, Dr. Daniel Bender, a psychiatrist at a child-and-​adolescent inpatient unit in Pittsburgh, sat in his office looking through his caseload. He had 12 patients, ages 10 to 17, half of whom had been admitted to the hospital for attempting suicide or for wrestling with ongoing thoughts about it. Some had psychotic disorders or behavioral problems. Most would stay in the hospital for several days to a couple of weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: The Speaker Gets His Chance to Go Toe-to-Toe With the President
description: Mr. McCarthy, who Republicans believe has been treated dismissively by Democrats, was buoyed by President Biden’s decision to negotiate more directly with him on the debt ceiling.
content: Speaker Kevin McCarthy got what he wanted out of Tuesday’s debt limit talks at the White House — the chance to go one-on-one against President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: How Victor Wembanyama Could Fit on the San Antonio Spurs
description: The Spurs know a thing or two about developing talented big men. But the once-stable franchise hasn’t been good for years.
content: Victor Wembanyama, the 7-foot-4 dynamic forward who is this year’s most prized N.B.A. prospect, cheered with his family in France as the San Antonio Spurs won the 2023 draft lottery Tuesday night. In San Antonio, fans, perhaps understandably, celebrated like they had won a championship, yelling in bars and honking car horns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Biden Taps Two Negotiators to Reach Debt Ceiling Deal With Republicans
description: President Biden selected Shalanda Young and Steve Ricchetti to talk directly with aides to Speaker Kevin McCarthy in an attempt to avoid default.
content: One of the biggest developments out of Tuesday’s debt ceiling meeting was President Biden’s selection of two officials to negotiate directly with aides to Speaker Kevin McCarthy: Shalanda Young, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Steve Ricchetti, a White House senior adviser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Russia’s aerial assault on Ukraine’s capital.
content: Russia launched an aerial assault of missiles and drones on Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, early yesterday morning, injuring at least three people, according to the authorities. But Ukrainian and American officials said Ukraine’s air defense shot down six hypersonic Kinzhal missiles, among the most sophisticated conventional weapons in Russia’s arsenal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
title: The Religious Right’s Hidden Sway as Japan Trails Allies on Gay Rights
description: As a G7 summit nears in Hiroshima, Japan is under pressure to show greater support for equality. A national Shinto group has spread a more hostile message.
content: To millions of Japanese, the Shinto faith is not so much a spiritual practice as a cultural one. Every January, crowds gather at shrines to pray for good fortune for the new year. Families take their children to celebrate rites of passage, and many seek blessings for luck in romance, school entrance exams or job interviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
title: Ecuador’s President Dissolves Congress Amid Impeachment Trial
description: President Guillermo Lasso disbanded the National Assembly as the opposition-led body was trying to oust him on embezzlement charges.
content: President Guillermo Lasso of Ecuador disbanded the country’s opposition-led National Assembly on Wednesday, a drastic move as the right-leaning leader faced impeachment proceedings over accusations of embezzlement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Lola Fadulu
title: Bike-Path Killer Is Sentenced to Life as Victims Speak Out
description: Sayfullo Saipov was convicted on 28 counts in the Manhattan terrorist attack, which killed eight people. The jury was unable to agree on a sentence of capital punishment.
content: A Manhattan jury had already decided that Sayfullo Saipov would be sentenced to life imprisonment on Wednesday for carrying out the 2017 terrorist attack on a West Side bike path that killed eight people, including six foreign tourists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Fair Warning: Lots of Passes, but Sotheby’s Modern Sales Still Bring in $427 Million
description: The Tuesday sales found stars in Magritte and Klimt, but the path for the art market is uncertain. Bidding is stingier than in the gonzo days of yesteryear.
content: Above the fireplace in the Los Angeles living room where the music executive Mo Ostin entertained celebrity clients like Frank Sinatra, Paul Simon and Joni Mitchell were two unusual paintings by René Magritte. The Belgian surrealist was still an acquired taste when Ostin started collecting him in the 1990s, long before the painter started commanding upwards of $50 million in the global art market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: Florida School District Is Sued Over Book Restrictions
description: A free-speech organization and the country’s largest book publisher said the district violated the First Amendment and the equal protection clause.
content: A lawsuit filed in federal court on Wednesday said that a Florida county violated the First Amendment by removing or restricting certain kinds of books from its school libraries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen to The Headlines, a Short Show on the Day’s Biggest News
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Who Stole Dorothy’s Ruby Slippers? A Minnesota Man Is Charged
description: An indictment charged Terry Jon Martin with stealing the red-sequined pumps from the Judy Garland Museum in Grand Rapids, Minn., in 2005. The slippers were recovered in a sting operation in 2018.
content: A Minnesota man has been indicted on charges that he stole a pair of the famed ruby slippers worn by Judy Garland in “The Wizard of Oz,” from the Judy Garland Museum in Grand Rapids, Minn., the actress’s hometown, nearly 18 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Remember When Trump and DeSantis Loved Each Other? Neither Do They.
description: Remember When Trump and DeSantis Loved Each Other? Neither Do They.
content: Our topic for today is — who’s worse, Donald Trump or Ron DeSantis?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Patricia Mazzei
title: DeSantis Signs Tall Stack of Right-Wing Bills as 2024 Entrance Nears
description: The Florida governor is making a grab for national attention ahead of his expected presidential campaign rollout.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, an all-but-declared presidential candidate, has stepped up his headline-hunting travel and events ahead of an official announcement, traversing the state and trying to hoover up national attention as he signs the sharply conservative legislation he believes can propel him to the Republican Party’s nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Biden Abruptly Cuts Short an Asia-Pacific Visit, to China’s Benefit
description: A Pacific island nation had gone to great lengths to host the U.S. president. Now a region is left to wonder again about American steadfastness.
content: It was meant to be a moment for the history books — the first time a U.S. president visited a Pacific Island country. Papua New Guinea, the host nation, scrambled to mobilize 1,000 security officers; the leaders of 17 other countries agreed to make the trip for just a few hours with President Biden, who was scheduled to go on to a meeting in Australia with allies known as the Quad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Heat Will Likely Soar to Record Levels in Next 5 Years, New Analysis Says
description: The World Meteorological Organization forecast “far-reaching repercussions for health, food security, water management and the environment.”
content: Global temperatures are likely to soar to record highs over the next five years, driven by human-caused warming and a climate pattern known as El Niño, forecasters at the World Meteorological Organization said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Cherelle Parker Wins Democratic Mayoral Primary in Philadelphia
description: If she wins the general election in November, she will be the first woman to lead the city.
content: After a crowded primary, Cherelle Parker, a former state representative and City Council member who campaigned on hiring more police, won the Democratic nomination for Philadelphia mayor on Tuesday night, emerging decisively from a field of contenders who had vied to be seen as the rescuer of a struggling and disheartened city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
title: Johannesburg, Where Mayors Last Just Months, or Even Only Weeks
description: South Africa’s largest city is now on its sixth different mayor in 22 months. While politicians argue over power, residents struggle with dry taps, heaps of garbage and dilapidated buildings.
content: NOW HIRING: A mayor of Johannesburg.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cannes 2023: Best Looks from the Red Carpet
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cannes Film Festival 2023: What to Know
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the document
description: Memo from the South Carolina Judicial Branch on state law allowing for the early release of inmates who provide help to law enforcement.
content: Memo from the South Carolina Judicial Branch on state law allowing for the early release of inmates who provide help to law enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy X. Wang
title: What Your Therapist Doesn't Tell You
description: A dozen counselors on what it’s really like to sit in the other armchair.
content: A dozen counselors on what it’s really like to sit in the other armchair.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Judge’s Order for the Release of Jeriod Price
description: The signed order from Judge Casey Manning allowing the early release of Jeriod Price.
content: The signed order from Judge Casey Manning allowing the early release of Jeriod Price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Deadly Flooding Leaves Thousands Homeless in Northern Italy
description: First responders rescued residents from flooded buildings after intense rainfall triggered widespread flooding.
content: First responders rescued residents from flooded buildings after intense rainfall triggered widespread flooding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Atlantic Productions/magellan
title: Scientists Create Detailed Digital Replica of the Titanic Shipwreck
description: A team of scientists scanned the historic Titanic shipwreck off the coast of Canada and created a 3-D model of the site.
content: A team of scientists scanned the historic Titanic shipwreck off the coast of Canada and created a 3-D model of the site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Adams Condemns Paparazzi Chasing Prince Harry and Meghan
description: Mayor Eric Adams described the incident as “reckless and irresponsible.” The couple were in New York City to attend the Women of Vision awards where Meghan was being honored.
content: Mayor Eric Adams described the incident as “reckless and irresponsible.” The couple were in New York City to attend the Women of Vision awards where Meghan was being honored.
source.name: The New York Times
